metadata.title: Personal Loan Payment Calculator — Bi‑Weekly & Monthly Comparison
metadata.description: Compare monthly, bi-weekly (26/year), and accelerated bi-weekly payment schedules for a personal loan. Shows periodic payment, number of payments, total paid, total interest and clear caveats on accuracy and compliance.

biweekly_26.label: Bi‑weekly payments (26/year)
biweekly_26.description: Fixed bi‑weekly payments, 26 payments per year (payment every two weeks). Calculates amortization using 26 periods per year.

accelerated_biweekly.label: Accelerated bi‑weekly (half monthly payment every two weeks)
accelerated_biweekly.description: Common accelerated method: compute monthly payment then make half of that payment every two weeks (results in 26 half‑payments/year). This often reduces total interest vs standard monthly payments.

introduction: This calculator compares monthly, bi‑weekly (26 payments per year), and accelerated bi‑weekly schedules for a personal loan. Enter the loan amount, APR, and term to see periodic payment amounts, number of payments, total paid and total interest for each method.

Results are produced using standard amortization formulas. Use the accelerated bi‑weekly method only if your lender or payroll arrangement supports making half‑monthly payments every two weeks; actual interest savings depend on timing of payments and lender posting policies.
methodology: Calculations assume a fixed interest rate and fixed scheduled payments for the loan term. The amortization formula used is the standard annuity formula for periodic payments: payment = P * r / (1 - (1+r)^-n), where r is the periodic rate and n is the total number of periods.

The accelerated bi‑weekly method shown uses half the monthly payment every two weeks which results in 26 half‑payments per year. That schedule reduces principal faster relative to monthly payments because the total paid annually is greater than 12 full monthly payments by an extra half‑payment per year.

Numerical calculations follow common engineering and finance practices and assume IEEE 754‑compatible floating point handling on the host system. For data handling and security we recommend implementation guidance from NIST. This tool provides estimates for planning purposes and is not a contract or offer.
how_is_calculated: 1) Convert APR to periodic rate: periodic_rate = annual_rate_percent / 100 / payments_per_year.
2) Compute total number of payments: number_payments = term_years * payments_per_year.
3) Compute periodic payment using annuity formula: periodic_payment = principal * periodic_rate / (1 - (1+periodic_rate)^(-number_payments)).
4) Compute totals: total_paid = periodic_payment * number_payments; total_interest = total_paid - principal.

5) Accelerated bi‑weekly approximation: monthly_payment = annuity formula with payments_per_year = 12; accelerated_periodic = monthly_payment / 2; approximate totals use accelerated_periodic * (term_years * 26).

faqs.question: Will bi‑weekly always save me interest?
faqs.answer: Generally, accelerated bi‑weekly schedules reduce interest because more frequent payments reduce principal earlier. Exact savings depend on payment timing and your lender's interest posting rules. This calculator gives an estimate based on standard amortization.

faqs.question: What is the difference between bi‑weekly and accelerated bi‑weekly?
faqs.answer: A standard bi‑weekly schedule with payments equal to the mathematically derived bi‑weekly payment differs from the accelerated method where you make half of a monthly payment every two weeks. The accelerated method usually yields extra annual payments (26 half‑payments) which can shorten the loan and lower interest.

faqs.question: How accurate are the numbers?
faqs.answer: Numbers are estimates produced by standard amortization formulas and typical floating‑point math. Small differences can occur due to rounding rules, lender-specific day count conventions, payment posting times, or additional fees. For exact payoff figures contact your lender.

faqs.question: Does this account for late fees, prepayment penalties or variable rates?
faqs.answer: No. This calculator assumes no fees, no prepayment penalties, and a fixed interest rate. If your loan includes fees, penalties, or variable rates, results will differ.

glossary.definition: Annual Percentage Rate — the yearly interest rate stated as a percentage, used to compute periodic interest.
The interest rate applied for each payment period, equal to APR divided by the number of payment periods per year.
A repayment approach where a borrower makes half of their monthly payment every two weeks (26 half‑payments per year), often shortening the loan term.
The mathematical formula used to compute fixed periodic payments that fully amortize a loan over a set number of periods.
